elements.content: The compound [Cu4(dpk·OCH3)2(N3)6] n [dpk = di-2-pyridylketone] consists of tetranuclear units that repeat in two dimensions. Predominant ferromagnetic interactions are in good agreement with the crystal structure, showing alternating Cu2(1,1)-azide2 and Cu2 (1,1)-azide-oxo bridging units. Rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges promote the two-dimensionality and cause the low temperature antiferromagnetism.
elements.clean_text: The compound [Cu4(dpk⋅OCH3)2(N3)6] n  [dpk = di-2-pyridylketone] consists of tetranuclear units that repeat in two dimensions. Predominant ferromagnetic interactions are in good agreement with the crystal structure, showing alternating Cu2(1,1)-azide2 and Cu2 (1,1)-azide-oxo bridging units. Rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges promote the two-dimensionality and cause the low temperature antiferromagnetism.

elements.content: A novel compound is synthesized using azide, dpk·CH3O−, and copper(II). Combination leads to the formation of tetranuclear entities built from alternating double (1,1)-azides and mixed (1,1)-azide-alkoxo units, further connected by rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges to give the unusual 2D structure. Predominant ferromagnetic interactions in the tetranuclear units with S = 2 are followed, at low temperature, by antiferromagnetic ones through (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges.
elements.clean_text: A novel compound is synthesized using azide, dpk⋅CH3O-, and copper(II). Combination leads to the formation of tetranuclear entities built from alternating double (1,1)-azides and mixed (1,1)-azide-alkoxo units, further connected by rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges to give the unusual 2D structure. Predominant ferromagnetic interactions in the tetranuclear units with S = 2 are followed, at low temperature, by antiferromagnetic ones through (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges.

elements.content: The preparation of ferromagnetic materials continues to be a challenge for scientists working in the field of molecular magnetism. It is in order to both design new synthesis mechanisms and obtain applicable properties that we have embarked in the search of new ferromagnetic molecular systems. Huge efforts have been made over the past few years not only in the synthesis of new high dimensional coordination polymers on the basis of concepts such as crystal engineering, molecular architecture, etc. but also in the synthesis of zero dimensional cluster materials such as single molecule magnets. In both cases, one of the desired targets is to obtain ferromagnetism. The right choice of ligands is key in the preparation of these compounds. Pseudohalides have been demonstrated to be not only extremely versatile but also excellent magnetic couplers. The azide and cyanate groups, in particular, are known to give ferromagnetic interactions in their end-on (1,1) bridging modes.
elements.clean_text: The preparation of ferromagnetic materials continues to be a challenge for scientists working in the field of molecular magnetism. It is in order to both design new synthesis mechanisms and obtain applicable properties that we have embarked in the search of new ferromagnetic molecular systems. Huge efforts have been made over the past few years not only in the synthesis of new high dimensional coordination polymers on the basis of concepts such as crystal engineering, molecular architecture, etc. but also in the synthesis of zero dimensional cluster materials such as single molecule magnets. In both cases, one of the desired targets is to obtain ferromagnetism. The right choice of ligands is key in the preparation of these compounds. Pseudohalides have been demonstrated to be not only extremely versatile but also excellent magnetic couplers. The azide and cyanate groups, in particular, are known to give ferromagnetic interactions in their end-on (1,1) bridging modes.

elements.content: Dpk-derivatives, on the other hand, exhibit a clear trend to form metallic clusters with interesting properties. The dpk ligand exhibits three potential donors, being able to chelate in bidentate (N,N or N,O) or tridentate (N,O,N) modes. Moreover, dpk has been observed occasionally to undergo solvolysis, resulting in a derivative product that can coordinate either as a neutral (dpk·ROH) or as an anionic (dpk·RO−) ligand. Compounds of higher dimensionality (1D or 2D) are very scarce.
elements.clean_text: Dpk-derivatives, on the other hand, exhibit a clear trend to form metallic clusters with interesting properties. The dpk ligand exhibits three potential donors, being able to chelate in bidentate (N,N or N,O) or tridentate (N,O,N) modes. Moreover, dpk has been observed occasionally to undergo solvolysis, resulting in a derivative product that can coordinate either as a neutral (dpk⋅ROH) or as an anionic (dpk⋅RO-) ligand. Compounds of higher dimensionality (1D or 2D) are very scarce.

elements.content: Following our previous work on dpk-pseudohalide ferromagnetic systems, we present in this article the synthesis, infrared spectroscopy, crystal structure, and magnetic characterization of the [Cu4(dpk·CH3O)2(N3)6] n (1) complex. This new compound represents the second example of a 2D complex containing dpk·CH3O−, in this case with only two bridging ligands: dpk·CH3O− itself and azide. Besides, it shows ferromagnetic interactions through alternating ···Cu-[(1,1)azide,oxo]-Cu-[(1,1)azide]2-Cu··· bridges. It also contains the rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridging mode, which gives rise to the two-dimensional structure for this complex.
elements.clean_text: Following our previous work on dpk-pseudohalide ferromagnetic systems, we present in this article the synthesis, infrared spectroscopy, crystal structure, and magnetic characterization of the [Cu4(dpk⋅CH3O)2(N3)6] n  (1) complex. This new compound represents the second example of a 2D complex containing dpk⋅CH3O-, in this case with only two bridging ligands: dpk⋅CH3O- itself and azide. Besides, it shows ferromagnetic interactions through alternating ⋅⋅⋅Cu-[(1,1)azide,oxo]-Cu-[(1,1)azide]2-Cu⋅⋅⋅ bridges. It also contains the rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridging mode, which gives rise to the two-dimensional structure for this complex.

elements.content: The crystal structure of 1 (Figure ) consists of Cu(II) cations linked by alternating double (1,1)-azide and mixed (1,1)-azide-alkoxo bridges. Rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges also connect the cations. The structure exhibits two crystallographically independent metallic centers that are distorted octahedrally coordinated (4 + 2).
elements.clean_text: The crystal structure of 1 (Figure ) consists of Cu(II) cations linked by alternating double (1,1)-azide and mixed (1,1)-azide-alkoxo bridges. Rare (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges also connect the cations. The structure exhibits two crystallographically independent metallic centers that are distorted octahedrally coordinated (4 + 2).

elements.content: ORTEP view of the asymmetric unit of 1 with 50% thermal ellipsoids, showing the atom-labeling scheme.
elements.clean_text: 1  ORTEP view of the asymmetric unit of 1 with 50% thermal ellipsoids, showing the atom-labeling scheme.

elements.content: The Cu2N2 bridging structural motifs are nearly planar (Cu···Cu = 3.284(5) Å; Cu1−N−Cu2 = 94.43(10), 101.73(10)°; torsion angle 176°), while the Cu2NO are not (Cu···Cu = 2.880(6) Å; Cu1−O1−Cu2 = 96.29(8)°, Cu1−N9−Cu2 = 91.15(9)°; torsion angle 142.5°). Both structural motifs conform a tetramer, [Cu4(dpk·CH3O)2(N3)6] (Figure ) that repeats along the [010] direction.
elements.clean_text: The Cu2N2 bridging structural motifs are nearly planar (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu = 3.284(5) Å; Cu1-N-Cu2 = 94.43(10), 101.73(10)°; torsion angle 176°), while the Cu2NO are not (Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu = 2.880(6) Å; Cu1-O1-Cu2 = 96.29(8)°, Cu1-N9-Cu2 = 91.15(9)°; torsion angle 142.5°). Both structural motifs conform a tetramer, [Cu4(dpk⋅CH3O)2(N3)6] (Figure ) that repeats along the [010] direction.

elements.content: Tetranuclear building block of [Cu4(dpk·CH3O)2(N3)6].
elements.clean_text: 2  Tetranuclear building block of [Cu4(dpk⋅CH3O)2(N3)6].

elements.content: Second tetranuclear building block formed by connection through (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges.
elements.clean_text: 3  Second tetranuclear building block formed by connection through (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges.

elements.content: Pairs of independent copper(II) ions are also connected by (1,1,3,3)-azides to conform a second tetranuclear building block (Figure ) that spreads in the (100) plane, joined by double (1,1)-azido bridges, to conform the global 2D structure (Figure ).
elements.clean_text: Pairs of independent copper(II) ions are also connected by (1,1,3,3)-azides to conform a second tetranuclear building block (Figure ) that spreads in the (100) plane, joined by double (1,1)-azido bridges, to conform the global 2D structure (Figure ).

elements.content: Global 2D structure of 1 in the (100) plane.
elements.clean_text: 4  Global 2D structure of 1 in the (100) plane.

elements.content: The thermal evolution, between 4.2 and 300 K, of the magnetic susceptibility is shown in Figure in the form of the χm T and χm −1 vs temperature plots. For temperatures higher than 130 K, a fit to a Curie−Weiss law gives values of C and θ of 0.41 cm3·K·mol−1 and +28 K, respectively, and a calculated g = 2.08. Below 130 K, the experimental data clearly deviate from the Curie−Weiss law. The obtained θ value is indicative of significant ferromagnetic exchange.
elements.clean_text: The thermal evolution, between 4.2 and 300 K, of the magnetic susceptibility is shown in Figure  in the form of the χm T and χm -1 vs temperature plots. For temperatures higher than 130 K, a fit to a Curie-Weiss law gives values of C and θ of 0.41 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 and +28 K, respectively, and a calculated g = 2.08. Below 130 K, the experimental data clearly deviate from the Curie-Weiss law. The obtained θ value is indicative of significant ferromagnetic exchange.

elements.content: The χm T (4 Cu) product continuously increases upon cooling from 1.78 cm3·K·mol−1 at room temperature (a value larger than that corresponding to four uncoupled CuII ions), up to a maximum of 2.32 cm3·K·mol−1 at 16 K. It approximately represents an enhancement by a 30% factor. Both the positive temperature intercept and the continuous increase of χm T with decreasing temperature until 16 K are in accord with the presence of significant ferromagnetic interactions in this 2D compound.
elements.clean_text: The χm T (4 Cu) product continuously increases upon cooling from 1.78 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at room temperature (a value larger than that corresponding to four uncoupled CuII ions), up to a maximum of 2.32 cm3⋅K⋅mol-1 at 16 K. It approximately represents an enhancement by a 30% factor. Both the positive temperature intercept and the continuous increase of χm T with decreasing temperature until 16 K are in accord with the presence of significant ferromagnetic interactions in this 2D compound.

elements.content: Thermal dependence of χm T and χm −1 (per 4 copper(II) ions). The dashed red curve represents the best fit for the model with negative zJ′ (iii), based upon a 2 J Hamiltonian.
elements.clean_text: 5  Thermal dependence of χm T and χm -1 (per 4 copper(II) ions). The dashed red curve represents the best fit for the model with negative zJ' (iii), based upon a 2 J Hamiltonian.

elements.content: Ferromagnetic coupling must be attributed to the exchange between coppers inside the tetranuclear unit. Furthermore, the 30% enhancement in χm T may indicate that this coupling is primarily between the coppers within each dinuclear unit of the tetramer (a uniform ferromagnetic tetramer will undergo an enhancement of 100%), that further ferromagnetically interact with each other. Interactions take place through the alternating double (1,1)-azido bridges [N3(N4−N5), N6(N7−N8)] and mixed (1,1)-azido-alkoxo bridges [N9(N10−N11), O1].
elements.clean_text: Ferromagnetic coupling must be attributed to the exchange between coppers inside the tetranuclear unit. Furthermore, the 30% enhancement in χm T may indicate that this coupling is primarily between the coppers within each dinuclear unit of the tetramer (a uniform ferromagnetic tetramer will undergo an enhancement of 100%), that further ferromagnetically interact with each other. Interactions take place through the alternating double (1,1)-azido bridges [N3(N4-N5), N6(N7-N8)] and mixed (1,1)-azido-alkoxo bridges [N9(N10-N11), O1].

elements.content: Below the maximum, the χm T product rapidly decreases, tending to zero. This decrease of the χm T product at low temperatures should be attributed to the antiferromagnetic interactions corresponding to the Cu2−N3−N4−N5−Cu2 intermetallic connections. Therefore, the compound would consist of ferromagnetically coupled tetramers with S = 2 that couple antiferromagnetically below 16 K.
elements.clean_text: Below the maximum, the χm T product rapidly decreases, tending to zero. This decrease of the χm T product at low temperatures should be attributed to the antiferromagnetic interactions corresponding to the Cu2-N3-N4-N5-Cu2 intermetallic connections. Therefore, the compound would consist of ferromagnetically coupled tetramers with S = 2 that couple antiferromagnetically below 16 K.

elements.content: There is no exact model for the susceptibility of a 2D lattice of heterogeneous exchange S = 1/2 tetramers. Notwithstanding, we have tried tentative fittings to (i) a dinuclear model (J Cu1−Cu2 = +55.3 K, g = 2.20); (ii) to dimers with an interdimer molecular field (J Cu1−Cu2 = +70.2 K, zJ′Cu1−Cu2 = +1.53 K, g = 2.16); (iii) and to dimers with the low temperature antiferromagnetic exchange as an interdimer molecular field (J Cu1−Cu2 = +43.7 K, zJ′ Cu1−Cu1 = −0.7 K, g = 2.23) (see Figure S6 of the ). Although neither of them are ideal, the estimated values of J and zJ′ are comparable to others found in the literature for Cu(II)-azide compounds. Our system compares partially with the observed tetranuclear units in the [Cu4(dpk·CH3O)2(Cl)6] n compound. In it, alternating ···Cu−Cl2−CuClO··· units promote ferromagnetic interactions (···Cu−(N3)2−Cu(N3)O··· in our case) that couple antiferromagnetically at low temperature. In this latter case, the obtained best J values are as follows: J 1 = +71.3 cm−1, J 2 = +1.4 cm−1, J 3 = +0.1 cm−1, zJ′ = −0.55 cm−1, and g = 2.1 (fixed). The (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges allow obtainment of the two dimensionality in our case.
elements.clean_text: There is no exact model for the susceptibility of a 2D lattice of heterogeneous exchange S = 1/2 tetramers. Notwithstanding, we have tried tentative fittings to (i) a dinuclear model (J Cu1-Cu2 = +55.3 K, g = 2.20); (ii) to dimers with an interdimer molecular field (J Cu1-Cu2 = +70.2 K, zJ'Cu1-Cu2 = +1.53 K, g = 2.16); (iii) and to dimers with the low temperature antiferromagnetic exchange as an interdimer molecular field (J Cu1-Cu2 = +43.7 K, zJ' Cu1-Cu1 = -0.7 K, g = 2.23) (see Figure S6 of the ). Although neither of them are ideal, the estimated values of J and zJ' are comparable to others found in the literature for Cu(II)-azide compounds. Our system compares partially with the observed tetranuclear units in the [Cu4(dpk⋅CH3O)2(Cl)6] n  compound. In it, alternating ⋅⋅⋅Cu-Cl2-CuClO⋅⋅⋅ units promote ferromagnetic interactions (⋅⋅⋅Cu-(N3)2-Cu(N3)O⋅⋅⋅ in our case) that couple antiferromagnetically at low temperature. In this latter case, the obtained best J values are as follows: J 1 = +71.3 cm-1, J 2 = +1.4 cm-1, J 3 = +0.1 cm-1, zJ' = -0.55 cm-1, and g = 2.1 (fixed). The (1,1,3,3)-azide bridges allow obtainment of the two dimensionality in our case.

elements.content: To corroborate the magnetic susceptibility observations, the magnetization versus applied field curves have been registered at 5 and 10 K (Figure ). The curve at 5 K indicates that the complex will saturate at 4 Böhr magnetons from four aligned S = 1/2 moments.
elements.clean_text: To corroborate the magnetic susceptibility observations, the magnetization versus applied field curves have been registered at 5 and 10 K (Figure ). The curve at 5 K indicates that the complex will saturate at 4 Böhr magnetons from four aligned S = 1/2 moments.

elements.content: Magnetization versus applied field at 5 and 10 K (per 4 copper(II) ions).
elements.clean_text: 6  Magnetization versus applied field at 5 and 10 K (per 4 copper(II) ions).

elements.content: These results are consistent with a ferromagnetically coupled high-spin Cu4 system with total S = 2. The field aligns the spins of the tetramers even at temperatures where antiferromagnetic coupling is observed. No electronic spin resonance spectrum is observed for 1 at room temperature, in good agreement with the presence of significant magnetic interactions.
elements.clean_text: These results are consistent with a ferromagnetically coupled high-spin Cu4 system with total S = 2. The field aligns the spins of the tetramers even at temperatures where antiferromagnetic coupling is observed. No electronic spin resonance spectrum is observed for 1 at room temperature, in good agreement with the presence of significant magnetic interactions.

It approximately represents an enhancement by a 30% factor. Both the positive temperature intercept and the continuous increase of χm T with decreasing temperature until 16 K are in accord with the presence of significant ferromagnetic interactions in this 2D compound.

metadata.title: Ferromagnetic Interactions in an Unusual 2D Coordination Polymer Including Di-2-pyridylketone-Methoxilated Anion, (1,1)-Azide, and Rare (1,1,3,3)-Azide Bridging Ligands
